docs.lead_paragraph: Employers are offering big incentives to steer workers into insurance plans that can save the company a lot of money, but what is the best fit for you?

headline.main: Making Sense of High-Deductible Health Plans

docs.lead_paragraph: When House Democrats talk about the public option, there is no single definition of what that means. In fact, there could soon be three definitions. The debate among Democrats over the public option -- a government-run insurance plan to compete with private insurers -- has mainly focused on two proposals. One is a ''robust'' plan, in which payments to doctors, hospitals and other providers would be tied to Medicare's rates. The other would require the government insurance program to negotiate its own payment rates.
docs.abstract: Debate among Democrats over public option--government-run insurance plan to compete with private insurers--has mainly focused on two proposals, but House leaders are exploring third approach: public plan that would start out with negotiated rates but would have fallback provision that would link rates to Medicare if plan was not saving enough money (S)
docs.snippet: When House Democrats talk about the public option, there is no single definition of what that means. In fact, there could soon be three definitions.      The debate among Democrats over the public option -- a government-run insurance plan to compete...

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Tom Harkin, the chairman of the Senate health committee, predicted Friday that Congress would pass sweeping health care legislation before Christmas. And he said it would include a new government insurance plan -- the so-called public option -- that would compete with private insurers. ''The vast majority of the Senate Democratic caucus is for the public option we have in our bill,'' which was approved by the health committee in July, Mr. Harkin said.
docs.abstract: Sen Tom Harkin predicts that Congress will pass sweeping health care legislation before Christmas, and that it will include so-called public option; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Senator Tom Harkin, the chairman of the Senate health committee, predicted Friday that Congress would pass sweeping health care legislation before Christmas. And he said it would include a new government insurance plan -- the so-called public option...

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Tom Harkin, the chairman of the Senate health committee, predicted on Friday that Congress would pass sweeping health care legislation before Christmas. And he said it would include a new government insurance plan -- the so-called public option -- which would compete with private insurers.

headline.main: Harkin Says Congress Will Pass Health Bill by Christmas - With a 'Public Option'

docs.abstract: The chairman of Senate health committee predicts Congress will overhaul legislation by Christmas, with a public insurance option.
docs.snippet: The chairman of Senate health committee predicts Congress will overhaul legislation by Christmas, with a public insurance option.

docs.lead_paragraph: On the Economix blog today, the economist Uwe E. Reinhardt deconstructs the widely shared complaint among hospital executives that Medicare and Medicaid pay less than their full share of hospital costs. The corollary argument, he writes, is that hospitals must therefore "recoup the shortfall by charging higher prices to private health insurers." It is an argument at the heart of the widely disputed cost analysis the insurance industry's trade group, America's Health Insurance Plans, issued this week, and Mr. Reinhardt finds that it is "a tall tale that taxes credulity." Read why he thinks so.

headline.main: Really? Do Lower Medicare Payments Force Other Insurers to Pay More?

docs.abstract: An economist rebuts the argument that Medicare and Medicaid's low payments to hospitals forces private insurers to pay more.
docs.snippet: An economist rebuts the argument that Medicare and Medicaid's low payments to hospitals forces private insurers to pay more.

docs.lead_paragraph: Today's Patient Money column explores the complicated world of consumer-driven health plans. As Walecia Konrad explains, these plans are really about putting the burden on you to reduce health care costs. Many employers are pushing these plans because they can save the company as much as 20 percent, compared with traditional insurance. She writes:

headline.main: High-Deductible Health Plans: Better for You or Your Employer?

docs.abstract: More employers are pushing consumer-driven health plans to help save money. But are they really good for consumers?
docs.snippet: More employers are pushing consumer-driven health plans to help save money. But are they really good for consumers?

docs.lead_paragraph: The Taxi and Limousine Commission will introduce new rules that would forbid the use of all electronics while cabs are in motion, The New York Post reports. Even the use of a hands-free device in an ear would be outlawed under the stringent new regulations.

headline.main: A Push to Ban Cellphone Use by Cabdrivers
